definition[0]: when a particular event or time has happened, or when someone has done something
example[0]: After the war many soldiers stayed in France.
example[1]: I go swimming every day after work.
example[2]: Do you believe in life after death?
example[3]: The first attack started just after midnight.
example[4]: David went to bed straight after (=immediately after) supper.
example[5]: After you’d called the police, what did you do?
example[6]: Zimmerman changed his name after he left Germany.
example[7]: People still remember the 1958 revolution and what came after (=happened after it).
example[8]: Ten years after he bought the painting, Carswell discovered that it was a fake.
example[9]: His car was outside your house the morning after Bob’s engagement party.
example[10]: I’ll see you again tomorrow or the day after.
example[11]: She retired from politics the year after she received the Nobel Prize.
example[12]: Not long after the wedding, his wife became ill.
example[13]: The family moved to Hardingham in June 1983, and Sarah’s first child was born soon after.
example[14]: After leaving school, Mackay worked in a restaurant for a year.
definition[1]: when a particular amount of time has passed
example[15]: After ten minutes remove the cake from the oven.
example[16]: You’ll get used to it after a while.
example[17]: After months of negotiation, an agreement was finally reached.
definition[2]: following someone or something else in a list or a piece of writing, or in order of importance
example[18]: Whose name is after yours on the list?
example[19]: The date should be written after the address.
example[20]: After football, tennis is my favourite sport.
example[21]: The UK is the world’s third largest arms producer, after the USA and Russia.
definition[3]: used when telling the time to say how many minutes have passed since a particular hour
example[22]: The movie starts at a quarter  (=fifteen minutes) after seven.
definition[4]: following someone in order to stop or speak to them
example[24]: I heard someone running after me, and a voice called my name.
definition[5]: in the direction of someone who has just left
example[25]: ‘Good luck, ’ she called after me as I left.
example[26]: Harry stood in the doorway gazing after her.
definition[6]: when someone has left a place or has finished doing something
example[27]: Remember to close the door after you.
example[28]: I spend all day cleaning up after the kids.
definition[7]: because of something that happened earlier
example[29]: I’m not surprised he walked out, after the way she treated him.
example[30]: After your letter, I didn’t think I’d ever see you again.
definition[8]: in spite of something that was done in the past
example[31]: How can you treat me like this after all I’ve done for you?
definition[9]: when you have passed a particular place or travelled a certain distance along a road
example[33]: After a mile you will come to a crossroads.
definition[10]: used to say who or what first had the name that someone or something has been given
example[34]: His name is Alessandro, after his grandfather.
example[35]: It was named Waterloo Bridge, after the famous battle.
definition[11]: in the same style as a particular painter, musician etc
definition[12]: used to say politely that someone else can use or do something before you do
definition[13]: used to ask someone if you can have or use something after they have finished
example[38]: After you with that knife, please.
definition[14]: after something happens, or after a period of time has passed. After is used especially when talking about the past
example[39]: We went for a walk after lunch.
example[40]: After an hour, we got tired of waiting and went home.
example[41]: They got married just after Christmas.
definition[15]: after a particular period of time. In is used especially when talking about the future, especially the next few minutes, hours, days etc
example[42]: The concert’s due to start in a few minutes.
example[43]: I’ll come back in an hour.
example[44]: In a few years’ time, this place will look completely different.
definition[16]: after less than a month, two weeks etc has passed – used especially when the time seems surprisingly short
example[45]: He developed a headache at lunchtime, and within two hours he was dead.
example[46]: Within two days of arriving she had managed to upset everyone.
definition[17]: at a time 24 hours, a year etc after now
example[47]: A week from now we’ll be in Paris.
definition[18]: after an event or time you have mentioned
example[48]: Jones admitted afterwards that she had been very nervous during the game.
example[49]: Speaking to reporters afterward, he said the operation had been a success.
example[50]: He moved to Belgium, and soon afterwards he met Angela.
definition[19]: some time after now or after the time you are talking about
example[51]: I’ll tell you about it later when I’m less busy.
example[52]: James went off, and came back ten minutes later with some food.
definition[20]: after something had happened in the past
example[53]: The book was published in 1954 and was subsequently translated into fifteen languages.
definition[21]: in the back part of a boat or an aircraft
